title: Relations and Functions
description: Explore the fundamental concepts of relations and functions, including types of relations, functions, composition of functions, and invertible functions.

content.text: A relation R from a non-empty set A to a non-empty set B is a subset of the Cartesian product A × B. The subset is derived by describing a relationship between the first element and the second element of the ordered pairs in A × B.

items: Reflexive: A relation R in a set A is reflexive if (a, a) ∈ R for every a ∈ A
Symmetric: A relation R in a set A is symmetric if (a, b) ∈ R implies (b, a) ∈ R for all a, b ∈ A
Transitive: A relation R in a set A is transitive if (a, b) ∈ R and (b, c) ∈ R implies (a, c) ∈ R for all a, b, c ∈ A
Equivalence: A relation R in a set A is an equivalence relation if R is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive

content.text: A function f from a set A to a set B is a specific type of relation where every element of set A has exactly one image in set B. This is denoted as f: A → B.

items: One-one (Injective): A function f: X → Y is one-one if f(x₁) = f(x₂) implies x₁ = x₂ for all x₁, x₂ ∈ X
Onto (Surjective): A function f: X → Y is onto if for every y ∈ Y, there exists an element x ∈ X such that f(x) = y
Bijective: A function f: X → Y is bijective if it is both one-one and onto

content.text: If f: A → B and g: B → C are two functions, then the composition of f and g, denoted by g∘f, is defined as the function g∘f: A → C given by (g∘f)(x) = g(f(x)) for all x ∈ A.

items: Composition is not commutative in general: f∘g ≠ g∘f
If f and g are one-one, then g∘f is also one-one
If f and g are onto, then g∘f is also onto

content.text: A function f: X → Y is invertible if there exists a function g: Y → X such that g∘f = Iₓ and f∘g = Iᵧ, where Iₓ and Iᵧ are identity functions on X and Y respectively.
A function is invertible if and only if it is bijective (both one-one and onto). The inverse of f is denoted by f⁻¹.
A binary operation ∗ on a set A is a function ∗: A × A → A. We denote ∗(a, b) by a ∗ b.

items: Commutative: a ∗ b = b ∗ a for all a, b ∈ A
Associative: (a ∗ b) ∗ c = a ∗ (b ∗ c) for all a, b, c ∈ A
Identity Element: There exists an element e ∈ A such that a ∗ e = e ∗ a = a for all a ∈ A
Inverse Element: For each a ∈ A, there exists an element b ∈ A such that a ∗ b = b ∗ a = e, where e is the identity element

questions.text: Relation R={(a,b): a−b divisible by 3} on Z is:
questions.explanation: This relation is reflexive (a-a=0 is divisible by 3), symmetric (if a-b is divisible by 3, then b-a is also), and transitive (if a-b and b-c are divisible by 3, then a-c is also).
To find the inverse, solve y = 3x+5 for x: x = (y-5)/3. Therefore, f⁻¹(x) = (x-5)/3.
By definition, a bijective function is both one-one (injective) and onto (surjective).

questions.text: If f: A→B and g: B→C, then g∘f is a function from:
questions.explanation: The composition g∘f maps elements from the domain of f (set A) to the codomain of g (set C).

questions.text: Which of the following is a binary operation on R?
questions.explanation: Both addition and subtraction are binary operations on R because they take two real numbers and produce another real number.

questions.text: No. of reflexive relations on set with 3 elements?
questions.explanation: For a reflexive relation on a set with n elements, the diagonal elements are fixed (n elements). The remaining n²-n elements can be chosen freely, giving 2^(n²-n) possibilities. For n=3: 2^(9-3) = 2⁶ = 64.
f(x)=x³ is one-one because if x₁³ = x₂³, then x₁ = x₂. It's also onto because for any real number y, there exists x = ∛y such that f(x) = y.

questions.text: An equivalence relation on a set divides it into:
questions.explanation: An equivalence relation partitions a set into disjoint equivalence classes, where each element belongs to exactly one class.
